Introduction

Social anxiety disorder (SAD) is characterized by anxiety and fear of scrutiny in social situations, resulting in avoidance, distress, and social-occupational dysfunction.  Fears are associated with acting in a way or showing anxiety symptoms (eg, blushing, sweating) that are negatively evaluated by others.

Epidemiology and risk factors

The estimated lifetime prevalence of SAD is 5%-12%.  Onset for the majority of patients is during childhood (ages 8-15), and female patients appear to be affected at a higher rate than male patients.

Several factors may increase the likelihood of developing SAD, including genetic predisposition (first-degree relative with SAD), psychological factors (eg, neuroticism, behavioral inhibition, introversion), and environmental factors (eg, adverse childhood events, bullying, discrimination, hypercritical parenting).

Clinical presentation

In SAD, anxiety and fear are elicited by situations in which exposure to scrutiny is possible, including:

  • Social interactions (eg, asking for help at a store, going on a date)
  • Being observed (eg, eating in a restaurant, using a public restroom)
  • Performing in front of others (eg, lecture, dance recital, wedding toast)

Before or during these situations, patients fear showing anxiety symptoms (eg, blushing, sweating, trembling) or acting in a way (eg, staring, stuttering) that will result in humiliation, embarrassment, and/or judgment (eg, being seen as anxious, unlikable, or offensive).

The fear and anxiety result in safety behaviors (eg, going to a party with a friend, excessive practicing before a performance) and avoidance (eg, relying on online ordering/shopping, a child refusing to go to school).

For diagnosis in children, anxiety and fear of social interactions must encompass interactions with both peers and adults (because a child's discomfort with speaking to adults is common).  Symptoms of SAD can appear differently in children; they may cry, freeze, or not speak at all.

The specifier "performance only" is used if the anxiety and fear are limited to speaking or performing in public (eg, giving a presentation, playing an instrument).  Patients with this type of SAD do not fear or avoid other types of social interactions (eg, meeting new people, going to a party, ordering at a restaurant).

Diagnosis

For a diagnosis of SAD, the following criteria must be met:

  • The patient has marked fear or anxiety about â‰¥1 social situation in which he or she is exposed to possible scrutiny by others.  Examples include social interactions (eg, having a conversation, meeting unfamiliar people), being observed (eg, eating or drinking), and performing in front of others (eg, giving a speech).  In children, anxiety must occur in peer settings and not just during interactions with adults.
  • The patient fears that he or she will show anxiety symptoms or act in a way that will be negatively evaluated (eg, will be humiliating or embarrassing, lead to rejection, or offend others).
  • Social situations almost always provoke fear or anxiety.  In children, fear or anxiety may be expressed by crying, tantrums, freezing, clinging, shrinking, or failing to speak in social situations.


  • Social situations are avoided or endured with intense fear or anxiety.
  • The fear or anxiety is out of proportion with the actual threat posed by the social situation.
  • The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is persistent, typically lasting â‰¥6 months.
  • The fear, anxiety, or avoidance causes clinically significant distress or impairment in important areas of functioning.
  • The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (eg, drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition.
  • The fear, anxiety, or avoidance is not better explained by the symptoms of another mental disorder (eg, panic disorder, autism spectrum disorder).
  • If another medical condition (eg, Parkinson disease, obesity, disfigurement from burns or injury) is present, the fear, anxiety, or avoidance is clearly unrelated or excessive.

Differential diagnosis

  • Normative shyness:  is common and also includes hesitancy and anxiety about social interactions.  However, this trait is less persistent and pervasive than SAD and is not associated with significant functional impairment; shyness can coincide with SAD, in which case both should be diagnosed.
  • Selective mutism:  can also include a fear of scrutiny or embarrassment and high social anxiety.  However, this disorder is limited to encounters in which speaking occurs and does not include other social situations (eg, eating in a restaurant, playing team sports, performing in a band).
  • Avoidant personality disorder:  also involves fears of negative evaluation in social situations and can co-occur with SAD; however, symptoms are much more pervasive and resistant to treatment, resulting in chronic low self-esteem and a sense of inadequacy.

Management

Management of SAD involves cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) and/or pharmacotherapy, depending on patient preference:

  • CBT specifically for SAD:
    • Involves identifying and reframing automatic negative thoughts associated with social interactions
    • Exposes patient to various feared situations in a guided and structured manner, resulting in decreased avoidance and improved tolerability
    • Promotes the use of coping skills instead of avoidance when anxiety arises
  • Selective-serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) (eg, sertraline, paroxetine) or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) (eg, venlafaxine)

Some patients have a subtype of SAD that affects them only during single or rare performance events (eg, giving a eulogy at a funeral).  For these patients, as-needed pharmacotherapy with a beta-adrenergic blocker (eg, propranolol) or a benzodiazepine (eg, clonazepam) may be considered.

Many patients with SAD have a coinciding psychiatric disorder; most commonly, this would be another anxiety disorder (eg, panic disorder), major depressive disorder, body dysmorphic disorder, or a substance use disorder.  Appropriate screening and treatment are recommended.

Prognosis

The course of SAD is variable.  Without treatment, some patients experience symptom improvement/remission with continued exposure to social interactions (eg, school, job that requires public speaking), whereas others experience persistent and debilitating symptoms with significant avoidance behaviors.  The majority of patients experience symptom improvement with treatment.

Summary
